journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: The effect of compatibility of suspension particles with the oil medium on electrorheological efficiency

article-meta.aff: 1Centre of Polymer Systems, University Institute, Tomas Bata University in Zlin, Zlin, Czech Republic
2Department of Polymer Engineering, Faculty of Technology, Tomas Bata University in Zlin, Zlin, Czech Republic

author-notes.corresp: Martin Stenicka, Tomas Bata University in Zlin, Faculty of Technology, Department of Polymer Engineering, Nam T. G. Masaryka 275, Zlin, 762 72, Czech Republic. Email: stenicka@ft.utb.cz

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on 12th International Conference on Electrorheological Fluids and Magnetorheological Suspensions - Part 2

abstract.p: The compatibility of solid phase–liquid medium appears to be an important factor for controlling the electrorheological (ER) efficiency of ER fluids. Controlled protonation of polyaniline particles with perfluorooctanesulfonic, tartaric, or sulphamic acid provides particles in a broad range of hydrophobicity as a suitable model to study this phenomenon. The relation between organization of such particles in silicone oil suspensions in on/off electric field at rest and during flow at various volume concentrations was demonstrated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: For more than 60 years, researchers have been fascinated by a unique behaviour of smart materials, which can be transformed from liquid-like to solid-like state after the application of an external electric or magnetic field (Winslow, 1947; Rabinow, 1948). These intelligent fluids usually consist of polarizable solid particles homogeneously dispersed in a non-conducting liquid medium, which organize themselves to chain-like or columnar structures in the electric field. This chaining is connected with a large change of rheological properties of the material—the viscosity of suspension steeply increases. When the external electric field disappears, the particle chains due to flow-field forces are destroyed and the suspension structure returns back to the original random state.

Since the discovery of electrorheological (ER) phenomenon, the main principles and mechanisms affecting the formation of such oriented structures have been summarized in several reviews (Block and Kelly, 1988; Block et al., 1990; Hao, 2001; Jordan and Shaw, 1989; Quadrat and Stejskal, 2006). Nevertheless, there are still some unexplained factors such as compatibility of the suspension particles with liquid phase that significantly influences rheological properties (Hato et al., 2011).

In our previous article (Stěnička et al., 2010), strong dependence of interfacial tension between polyaniline (PANI) particles and silicone oil–based suspensions on ER efficiency in both steady shear and oscillatory mode has been described. PANI (Stejskal and Gilbert, 2002) has been advisedly chosen as a model material because of its unique properties. Simple preparation, relatively easy way to control the conductivity, reduced sedimentation, non-corrosive properties, and so on make PANI interesting from ER application point view (Choi and Jhon, 2009; Quadrat and Stejskal, 2006). Besides the conductivity control (Choi et al., 1998), wettability of PANI particles can be controlled by the process of protonation with corresponding acid (Stejskal et al., 2008).

In the present study, the differences in formation and rheological behaviour of ER structure of the PANI particles modified by three different acids influencing their mutual compatibility to silicone oil are investigated.

sec.title: Synthesis of PANI Particles
sec.p: PANI is prepared by the oxidation of aniline in aqueous acidic medium. The standard procedure consists of the oxidation of 0.2 M aniline hydrochloride with 0.25 M ammonium peroxydisulphate (Stejskal et al., 2008) at room temperature. The PANI salt obtained in this manner was converted to a PANI base in excess of 1 M ammonium hydroxide and dried. The conductivity of the PANI base was 3.60 × 10−9 S cm−1. The 2 g portions of PANI base were further suspended in 40 mL of aqueous acid solutions for 24 h (Stejskal and Gilbert, 2002). The resulting reprotonated PANI was collected on a filter, rinsed with acetone, and dried at room temperature in air and later in a desiccator. Four suspensions of PANI particles with significant difference in hydrophobicity, and thus in compatibility to silicone oil, were employed (P1–P4; Table 1).

caption.p: The water contact angle (θ), density (ρ) and conductivity (σ) of PANI base reprotonated in the aqueous solutions of various acids.

sec.title: ER Fluids
sec.p: ER fluids (1.2–20 vol% of solids) were prepared by mixing PANI particles with corresponding amount of silicone oil (Lukosiol M200, Chemical Works Kolin, Czech Republic; viscosity ηc = 200 mPa s, density ρc = 0.965 g cm−3, conductivity σc ≈ 10−11 S cm−1). The suspensions were deposited in a desiccator and stirred at first mechanically, then in an ultrasonic bath for 30 s before each ER measurement.

sec.title: ER Measurements
sec.p: Rheological measurements were carried out with a rotational rheometer Bohlin Gemini (Malvern Instruments, UK), with parallel plates 40 mm in diameter and a 0.5 mm gap, equipped with ER cell. The plates were connected to a direct current (DC) high-voltage source TREK 668B (TREK, USA) providing the intensity of the electric field strength, E = 0–500 V mm−1. Before each measurement, the suspension structure was homogenized by shearing of the suspension at the shear rate 20 s−1 for 100 s. The measurements were performed under room temperature.

sec.title: Monitoring of ER Structure
sec.p: The formation of ER structures was monitored by optical microscope Olympus CX31 (Olympus, Japan). The electric field strength E = 200 V mm−1 was achieved by an electrometer Keithley 6517B (Keithley, USA). The micrographs of suspensions were obtained by a digital camera Olympus Camedia C-4000 Zoom (Olympus, Japan).

sec.title: Structure of Suspensions
sec.p: The micrographs (Figures 1 and 2) demonstrate that the protonation of PANI particles with various acids significantly influence their organization in silicone oil suspension. The hydrophobic particles (Table 1; P1) treated with perfluorooctanesulfonic acid were homogeneously dispersed in continuous phase because of similar wettability. Thus, obviously only slight particle interactions set in (Figure 1(a)). By contrast, however, the hydrophilic particles (P4) protonated with sulphamic acid created fine chain or network structures already in the absence of the electric field (Figure 2(a)). When the electric field was applied, the former particles (P1) were polarized and joined the electrodes by distinct chains (Figure 1(b)). In the latter case, the original field-off particle arrangement changed in a dense chain-like structure oriented along the streamlines of the electric field (Figure 2(b)).

caption.p: Micrographs of 1.2 vol% silicone oil suspensions of PANI particles protonated by perfluorooctanesulfonic acid (P1) (a) before and (b) after application of electric field E = 200 V mm−1.
Micrographs of 1.2 vol% silicone oil suspensions of PANI particles protonated by sulphamic acid (P4) (a) before and (b) after application of electric field E = 200 V mm−1.

sec.title: Steady Shear
sec.p: The shear stress–shear rate dependencies of the suspensions of four particle samples under study at three volume fractions in the absence (Figure 3) and in the presence (Figure 4) of the electric field showed that marked differences in suspension structure at rest are also significant at flow. The distinct effect of various particle compatibilities on flow character already appeared in the absence of electric field (Figure 3). The suspensions of hydrophobic particles (P1) were nearly Newtonian at all three particle concentrations. On the other hand, in suspensions of hydrophilic particles (P4) a significant non-Newtonian flow set in. Suspensions of rather hydrophobic (P2) and rather hydrophilic (P3) particles tended to Newtonian behaviour at lower concentrations (5 and 10 vol%) and behaved as non-Newtonian at 20 vol% with marked yield-stress value. This evidently corresponds to the differences in character of particle organization as shown in Figures 1 and 2.

caption.p: The shear stress (τ) versus shear rate (γ̇) dependence of PANI suspensions in (a) 5 vol%, (b) 10 vol%, and (c) 20 vol% in the absence of the electric field. Symbols: ■ P1, ◇ P2, ▲ P3, and ▽ P4.

The shear stress (τ) versus shear rate ($\dot \rgamma $) dependence of PANI suspensions in (a) 5 vol%, (b) 10 vol%, and (c) 20 vol% at the electric field strength, E = 200 V mm−1. Symbols denoted as in Figure 3.

sec.p: After the electric field application, the shear stress increases for all suspensions as a consequence of the particle chaining (Figure 4). The effect of particle compatibility to silicone oil medium on ER activity at various particle concentrations was demonstrated by the shear stress τγ̇ = 1 evaluated at the shear rate γ̇ = 1s−1 (Figure 5). It is obvious that unlike suspensions of more hydrophobic particles P1, P2, and P3, the increase in the shear stress in the suspension of hydrophilic particles (P4) in the presence of the electric field was relatively low. Consequently, the ER performance, e = (τE=200 − τE=0)/τE=0, where τE=200 is the shear stress under electric field application and τE=0 its field-off value, was much lower, especially at high-particle concentrations (Figure 6).

caption.p: The shear stress (τγ̇ = 1) versus particle concentration (φ) dependence of PANI suspensions in the absence (open) and in the presence (solid) of electric field strength, E = 200 V mm−1. Symbols: (a) (□■) P1, (b) (◇◆) P2, (c) (△▲) P3, and (d) (▽▼) P4.
The dependence of the relative stress, e = (τE=200 − τE=0)/τE=0, on the volume fraction of PANI particles (φ). Symbols denoted as in Figure 3.

sec.p: It is clear that the highest e-value in the more hydrophobic sample (P1) was a consequence above all of the low shear stress in the absence of electric field caused by good particle–oil medium compatibility. On the contrary strong interaction between hydrophilic particles (P4) resulted in high τE=0 value; the ER efficiency was low and decreased when the concentration of the particles increased (Figure 6). The ER performance of rather hydrophobic (P2) and rather hydrophilic (P3) laid between samples P1 and P4, whereas the optimal concentration of PANI particles for maximum ER response was around 10 vol%. This corresponds to observations in the earlier study (Lengálová et al., 2003), where a similar optimum concentration for commercially available PANI base was found.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study illustrates that the compatibility between suspension particles and silicone oil crucially affects flow behaviour both in the absence and in the presence of the electric field. A low particle–particle interaction in suspensions of hydrophobic particles causes a low field-off shear stress and, consequently, high ER performance in a broad range of volume concentrations. In contrast, low compatibility of hydrophilic particles with silicone oil results in the formation of interparticle bonding. The shear stress of this chain-like or network suspension structure in the absence of the electric field due to limited mobility of the particles is high and, as a result, the relative shear stress is considerably lower than in suspensions of hydrophobic particles.
